code: @Manual{,   title = {gatoRs: gatoRs},   author = {Natalie Patten},   year = {2023},   note = {https://nataliepatten.github.io/gatoRs/, https://github.com/nataliepatten/gatoRs}, }

title: gatoRs
text: Natalie N. Patten, Michelle L. Gaynor, Douglas E. Soltis, Pamela S. Soltis

title: gatoRs
text: gatoRs (Geographic Taxonomic Occurrence R-Based Scrubbing) provides users tools downloading processing biodiversity data.

title: gatoRs
gatoRs
text: download data using gators_download(), need list possible names species (including synonyms), first name list accepted name using species code option GBIF search. also need path name file, including “.csv” ending. Example: Optional parameters include gbif_match idigbio_filter. gbif_match allows search fuzzy matching records scientific name (default, gbif_match = "fuzzy") search associated species key using GBIF’s backbone taxonomy system (gbif_match = "code"). set TRUE (default, recommended), idigbio_filter fuzzy matches taxonomic columns provided taxon names. filters data set relevant data. function also generates scientificName, genus, specificEpithet, infraspecificEpithet columns based available data parsing fixes incorrect capitalization species names give data cleaner look. overview returned data summarized table .
code: gators_download(synonyms_list = c("Asclepias curtissii", "Asclepias aceratoides",                                   "Asclepias arenicola", "Oxypteryx arenicola",                                    "Oxypteryx curtissii"),                  newFileName = "base_folder/other_folder/my_file.csv")

text: find data lacking coordinates containing locality information, use need_to_georeference(). Use downloaded data first step input. georeference records manually enter information data set. Example:

title: gatoRs
text: find data containing scientific names corresponding desired species, use filter_select_name(). Use downloaded data first step input, well synonyms list, accepted name, filter option (exact, fuzzy, interactive). Example:
code: occurrence_records <- filter_select_name(occurrence_records, synonyms_list = c("Asclepias curtissii", "Asclepias aceratoides", "Asclepias arenicola", "Oxypteryx arenicola", "Oxypteryx curtissii"), filter = "interactive", accepted_name = "Asclepias curtissii")

title: Filter iDigBio results by scientific name — filter_fix_names
text: filter_fix_names() function filters data frame relevant results, based scientific name given. downloaded results iDigBio might contain occurrences species "notes" mentioning desired species. Hence, function looks relevant results actually occurrences desired species.

title: Filter data frame for relevant results — filter_select_name
text: filter_select_name() function filters data frame relevant results, based scientific name given. Filtering can done scripts exact fuzzy match. , controlled approach, function provides interactive filtering providing user prompts. interactive method allows user manually determine whether wish keep results containing certain scientific names.

what: Perform final cleaning of data — final_clean
title: Perform final cleaning of data — final_clean
text: final_clean() function performs final cleaning steps, including: removing duplicate data points, checking locality precision, retaining one collection point. function also provides option interactively inspect remove types basis record.

title: Perform final cleaning of data — final_clean
code: final_clean(df, cluster = TRUE, precision = 2, recordBasis = TRUE)

title: Perform final cleaning of data — final_clean
text: df Data frame occurrence records. cluster option (TRUE/FALSE) cluster geographically close occurrence records. option turned default. precision option round coordinates specified number digits. option set 2 default. use rounding, choose precision = NA. recordBasis option (TRUE/FALSE) interactively remove types basis record. option turned default.

title: Perform final cleaning of data — final_clean
text: df data frame cleaned data.

title: Perform final cleaning of data — final_clean
text: function requires packages dplyr, magrittr, raster, dismo.

what: Download data from both iDigBio and GBIF — gators_download
title: Download data from both iDigBio and GBIF — gators_download
text: gators_download() function downloads data GBIF iDigBio desired species. Data returned includes: scientificName, genus, specificEpithet, infraspecificEpithet, basisOfRecord, eventDate, institutionCode, collectionCode, collectionID, country, county, stateProvince, locality, latitude, longitude, identificationID, coordinateUncertaintyInMeters, informationWithheld, habitat.

title: Download data from both iDigBio and GBIF — gators_download
code: gators_download(   synonyms_list,   newFileName,   gbif_match = "fuzzy",   idigbio_filter = TRUE )

title: Download data from both iDigBio and GBIF — gators_download
text: synonyms_list list synonyms desired species. example, synonyms_list = c("Asclepias curtissii","Asclepias aceratoides", "Asclepias arenicola", "Oxypteryx arenicola", "Oxypteryx curtissii"). parameter required. newFileName path file name retrieved data. Note parameter include ".csv" extension well. example, newFileName = "base_folder/other_folder/my_file.csv". file path can entered either relative current working directory (example: "../my_file.csv") full path. parameter required. gbif_match parameter select either search fuzzy matching scientific name search species code. example, gbif_match = "fuzzy" search fuzzy match gbif_match = "code" search code. parameter required assigned "fuzzy" default. idigbio_filter parameter remove less relevant search results iDigBio. Based search input, results may include data points different species mention desired species locality information, example. Choosing idigbio_filter = TRUE return data frame rows name column fuzzy matches name synonym list. parameter required assigned TRUE default.

title: Download data from both iDigBio and GBIF — gators_download
text: Writes csv file specified input. csv file contain search results desired species GBIF iDigBio databases.

title: Download data from both iDigBio and GBIF — gators_download
text: function uses getidigbio(), getgbif(), fix_columns(), fix_names(), filter_fix_names() functions. function requires packages magrittr, rgbif, dplyr, ridigbio, stringr.

title: Download data from both iDigBio and GBIF — gators_download
code: gators_download(c("Asclepias curtissii", "Asclepias aceratoides", "Asclepias arenicola", "Oxypteryx arenicola", "Oxypteryx curtissii"), "my_new_file.csv", idigbio_filter = FALSE) #> [1] "Warning: iDigBio search will return all records where any column has a matching string to the provided scientific names." gators_download(c("Asclepias curtissii", "Asclepias aceratoides", "Asclepias arenicola", "Oxypteryx arenicola", "Oxypteryx curtissii"), "newFile.csv", gbif_match = "code")
